CricketMatch.MatchReport:
Let down by their scheduled opposition (Falklands - Two years running now) Twyford used the Conference to arrange a new match away at Penn Street - A delightful village between High Wycombe & Amersham with not one but three cricket pitches within about 500 meters of eachother, all (apparently) opposite Pubs! The game was arranged to begin at 10:00am because there was some sort of association football (soccer) match on in the afternoon the many players wished to observe.

Twyford won the toss and elected to field. This was probably the correct decision, but with the short, dry outfield and what turned out to be a true wicket meant that it was going to feel like a long time in the field for the visitors! Opening line and length was not all it could have been, and Penn St. made hay. But as time progressed Twyford managed to rein in the scoring rate, and succeeded in sending the openers back to the pavilion. But then Collinson came to the crease. Never looking particularly troubled by the attack he dispatched the ball to the boundary so often that Twyford had no answer. Good fielding from the visitors did not matter - He found the gaps. Ably supported by Lofty who scored 65, Collinson ended on a huge 152 not out - An excellent performance.

Nevertheless, Twyford may have been lacking in bowling, but 10 of the side has performed well with the bat this season, and the large total was perhaps not completely beyond their reach. And indeed Woodman & Benjamin started well, many boundaries flying and the required run-rate being achieved. Benjamin had to leave the field for a while when he top-edged a ball onto his forward (Nasty cut - No permanent damage). Indeed it was not until the 16th over when the first wicket fell - Woodman continuing his excellent season with another 50. But Twyford could not maintain. Disappointed batsmen returned regularly to the pavilion (Well, actually the garden of the Pub opposite - So at least they could drown their sorrows), unhappy that with such a lovely batting track they had not scored more. Only Hill - Playing his fist game in 8 years, and Walkland with his first (And very aggressive!) 50 for the club shone. The well deserved victory belonged to Penn Street.

A fine time was has by all, and it was agreed that these two teams who met by accident through the Cricket Club Conference should repeat the fixture in the following years.
